title: Understanding Gendered Agency in Violent Conflict: Extending Conceptual and Methodological Parameters
abstractText:
The post Cold War era has seen the emergence of a general consensus
around the need to rethink war. In place of the ‘classic’ inter-state model,
there are conflicts with  very few actual engagements between organised
military forces.  The  battlegrounds are civilians’ homes and combatants not
recognisable as national militaries.  This type of  violence can engulf entire
regions and produce new patterns of  national boundaries. These shifts in the realities of armed conflict have not just affected the military sector. Many humanitarian and development agencies now find themselve operating in conflict zones.

These shifts all have implications for the study of gender relations,
particularly those  around conflict and violence. For example, women –
especially mothers - have commonly been associated with a ‘pro-peace’
position, and there are certainly many important initiatives of this
kind in conflict zones. However, at the same time, women have sustained
violent conflict in a number of ways. Despite  conventional assumptions
about male aggression, there are also  many instances of men
refusing/avoiding involvement in armed conflict.

This seminar series will provide an opportunity to examine these shifts  in
detail and to relate them to current policy initiatives e.g. around sexual
violence in war.
